intro: Allocarya cusickii var. jucunda, commonly known as the Desert Evening Primrose, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in the evening, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, thriving in well-drained soils and full sun. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and often branched. The species is part of the genus Allocarya, which includes several other desert plants adapted to harsh, dry conditions.
